BookInfo.BookSubTitle: Towards Chemical Accuracy for Chemistry of Main Group Elements

ChapterInfo.ChapterTitle: An Overview of Modern Density Functional Theory

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Density functional theory (DFT) has become the leading method in computing the electronic structures and properties from first principles. Its foundation was laid on Hohenberg-Kohn theorems, which proved that there exists a one-to-one correspondence between the ground state electron density ρ0 of a many-body system and its total energy. In practice, DFT is most frequently applied in the framework of Kohn–Sham (KS) scheme, where an approximate exchange-correlation functional has to be chosen. Hence, the success of a DFT calculation critically depends on the quality of the exchange-correlation functional. In this chapter, we first briefly discuss the Hohenberg-Kohn theorems (Sect. 1.1). After introducing the KS scheme, various approximations for the exchange-correlation functionals are presented in Sect. 1.2. These functionals are grouped according to Perdew’s classification of Jacob’s ladder. Finally, some general trends for the functional performances along the Jacob’s ladder are outlined.

Section2.Heading: Wavefunction Versus Density as Basic Variables
Section2.Para:
The ultimate goal of most quantum chemical applications is to solve the time-independent, non-relativistic Schrödinger equation: [1, 2]. 1.1
$$ \hat{H}\Uppsi \left( {\vec{r}_{1} \sigma_{1} , \ldots ,\vec{r}_{N} \sigma_{N} } \right) = E\Uppsi \left( {\vec{r}_{1} \sigma_{1} , \ldots ,\vec{r}_{N} \sigma_{N} } \right) $$ where
$$ \hat{H} $$ is the Hamilton operator for a molecular system consisting of N electrons in the presence of an external potential
$$ \upsilon_{\text{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ . 1.2
$$\begin{array}{l} \hat{H} = - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{{i = 1}}^{N} {\nabla _{i}^{2} } + \sum\limits_{{i = 1}}^{N} {\upsilon _{{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} + \sum\limits_{{i = 1}}^{N} {\sum\limits_{{j > i}}^{N} {\frac{1}{{\left| {\vec{r}_{i} - \vec{r}_{j} } \right|}}} } \\ {\rm{ }} = \hat{T} + \hat{V}_{{ext}} + \hat{V}_{{ee}} \\ \end{array}$$

The first term on the right describes the kinetic operator
$$ \hat{T} $$ , where the Laplacian operator
$$ \nabla_{i}^{2} $$ is defined as a sum of second-order differential operators (in Cartesian coordinates) 1.3
$$ \nabla_{i}^{2} = \frac{{\partial^{2} }}{{\partial x_{i}^{2} }} + \frac{{\partial^{2} }}{{\partial y_{i}^{2} }} + \frac{{\partial^{2} }}{{\partial z_{i}^{2} }} $$

The last term in Eq. 1.2 describes the electron–electron repulsion
$$ \hat{V}_{\text{ee}} $$ that sums over all distinct pairs of different electrons. The external potential
$$ \upsilon_{\text{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ generally comes from the electrostatic interaction between electrons and nuclei, where
$$ \left\{ {Z_{\alpha } ,\,\vec{R}_{\alpha } } \right\} $$ indicate the nuclear charges and their spatial coordinates, respectively. 1.4
$$ \upsilon_{\text{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = - \sum\limits_{\alpha } {\frac{{Z_{\alpha } }}{{\left| {\vec{R}_{\alpha } - \vec{r}} \right|}}} $$

$$ \Uppsi \left( {\vec{r}_{1} \sigma_{1} , \ldots ,\vec{r}_{N} \sigma_{N} } \right) $$ stands for the wavefunction of the system, which depends on the 3N spatial coordinates
$$ \left\{ {\vec{r}_{i} } \right\} $$ , and the N spin coordinates
$$ \left\{ {\sigma_{i} } \right\} $$ of the electrons. The wavefunction
$$ \Uppsi $$ contains all information that can possibly be known for the quantum system that we are interested in. Nevertheless, as electrons are inter-connected by
$$ \hat{V}_{\text{ee}} $$ , it is very difficult to find a good approximation to the solution of Eq. 1.1 for N > 1 [1–4].

The electron density
$$ \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ is given by [1–4] 1.5
$$\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = N\int {...\int {\left| {\Psi \left( {\vec{r}\sigma _{1} ,...,\vec{r}_{N} \sigma _{N} } \right)} \right|^{2} {\rm{d}}\vec{r}_{2} ...{\rm{d}}\vec{r}_{N} {\rm{d}}\sigma _{1} ...{\rm{d}}\sigma _{N} } } $$

It determines the probability of finding any of the N electrons within the volume element
$$ {\text{d}}\vec{r} $$ but with arbitrary spin while the other N − 1 electrons have arbitrary positions and spins in the state represented by
$$ \Uppsi $$ . As
$$ \Uppsi $$ is normalized, it is clear, from Eq. 1.5, one has 1.6
$$ \int {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right){\rm d}\vec{r}} = N $$

Unlike the wavefunction, electron density always depends on only three spatial coordinates, and it is an observable that may be measured experimentally via, e.g., X-ray diffraction. If, instead of the complicated N-electron wavefunction
$$ \Uppsi $$ , the electron density
$$ \rho $$ could be used as the basic variable, such an approach would be physically more appealing and computationally more efficient.

Section2.Heading: Hohenberg-Kohn Theorems
Section2.Para:
Hohenberg-Kohn theorems put the modern density functional theory (DFT) onto a firm physical foundation [2–6]. The first Hohenberg-Kohn theorem is often quoted as “proof of existence” [5], which stated that “the external potential
$$ \upsilon_{\text{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ is (to within a constant) a unique functional of
$$ \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ ; since, in turn
$$ \upsilon_{\text{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ fixes
$$ \hat{H} $$ we see that the full many particle ground state is a unique functional of
$$ \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ ” [5]. The existence of a one-to-one correspondence between the ground state electron density
$$ \rho_{0} $$ of a many-body system and its Hamiltonian
$$ \hat{H} $$ equivalently proved that there exists an energy functional in terms of density, that is
$$ E\left[ \rho \right] $$ .

At this point, it is instructive to separate the energy expression of
$$ E\left[ \rho \right] $$ into its components, as the external potential energy
$$ V_{\text{ext}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ , in terms of electrons-nuclei attractions, is readily expressed as a functional of
$$ \rho $$ . 1.7
$$ \begin{gathered} E\left[ \rho \right] = F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] + V_{\text{ext}} \left[ \rho \right] \hfill \\ \, = F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] + \int {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \upsilon_{\text{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right){\text{d}}\vec{r} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$

$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ is the so-called Hohenberg-Kohn functional, which shall consist of the kinetic energy functional
$$ T\left[ \rho \right] $$ for electron and the electron–electron repulsion energy functional
$$ V_{\text{ee}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ . 1.8
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] = T\left[ \rho \right] + V_{\text{ee}} \left[ \rho \right] $$

As the classic Coulomb energy
$$ J\left[ \rho \right] $$ among electrons is the major contributor of
$$ V_{\text{ee}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ , and its expression as a functional of
$$ \rho $$ is known, it is also instructive to separate
$$ J\left[ \rho \right] $$ from its non-classic counterpart
$$ E_{\text{ncl}} \left[ \rho \right] = V_{\text{ee}} \left[ \rho \right] - J\left[ \rho \right] $$ . 1.9
$$ J\left[ \rho \right] = \frac{1}{2}\iint {\frac{{\rho \left( {\vec{r}'} \right)\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}}{{\left| {\vec{r}' - \vec{r}} \right|}}}{\rm d}\vec{r}'{\text{\rm d}}\vec{r} $$

Hence the energy expression for
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ now reads as 1.10
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] = T\left[ \rho \right] + J\left[ \rho \right] + E_{\text{ncl}} \left[ \rho \right] $$

As every electron is identical,
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ is a universal functional, whose form is independent of a particular molecular system (i.e., independent of charges and positions of the nuclei).

The second Hohenberg-Kohn theorem is the variational principle in terms of density [5]. It tells us that functional
$$ E\left[ \rho \right] $$ attains its minimum value with respect to all allowed densities (i.e., Eq. 1.6 is fulfilled), if and only if the input density is the true ground state density. 1.11
$$ E\left[ {\rho_{0} } \right] = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\rho \to N} E\left[ \rho \right] $$
This constrained variation on density is equivalent to solving the Euler Equation

1.13 [2–6]. 1.12
$$ \delta \left[ {E\left[ \rho \right] - \mu \int {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right){\text{d}}\vec{r}} } \right] = 0 $$
1.13
$$\mu = \upsilon _{{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \frac{{\delta F_{{HK}} \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} $$

Hence the electronic chemical potential appears as a Lagrange multiplier
$$ \mu $$ in DFT.

The Hohenberg-Kohn theorems are the bedrocks of modern DFT, which prove the unique mapping between the ground state density
$$ \rho_{0} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ and the ground state energy
$$ E\left[ {\rho_{0} } \right] $$ . They, however, do not provide any guidance on how
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ should be constructed for practical use. In fact,
$$ T\left[ \rho \right] $$ is a major contributor of
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ . Even the 1 % error in the kinetic energy will prevent DFT from being used as a quantitative predictive tool [3, 7, 8].

Section2.Heading: Kohn–Sham Scheme
Section2.Para:
The Kohn–Sham (KS) scheme [2–4, 9] provides an avenue that the large part of the kinetic energy can be approached to good accuracy. This was, however, achieved by utilizing an orbital representation. It is assumed that, for any real (interacting) system, there exists a local single particle potential
$$ \upsilon_{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ corresponding to a fictitious (non-interacting fermion) system, whose ground state density
$$ \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ equals the exact ground state density
$$ \rho_{0} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ . Such a system is defined by the Hamiltonian 1.14
$$\hat{H}_{s} = \sum\limits_{{i = 1}}^{N} {\left( { - \frac{1}{2}\nabla _{i}^{2} + \upsilon _{s} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} \right)} $$ which has an exact wavefunction solution that is the single Slater determinant constructed from the N lowest orbitals of the one-electron equations 1.15
$$\left( { - \frac{1}{2}\nabla ^{2} + \upsilon _{s} (\vec{r})} \right)\phi _{i} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \varepsilon _{i} \phi _{i} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$

For this system the kinetic energy and electron density are given by 1.16
$$T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] = - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{{i = 1}}^{N} {\int {\phi _{i}^{*} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\nabla ^{2} \phi _{i} \left( {\vec{r}} \right){\rm{d}}\vec{r}} } $$
1.17
$$ \rho (\vec{r}) = \sum\limits_{i = 1}^{N} {\left| {\phi_{i} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \right|^{2} } $$ and its total energy is given by 1.18
$$ E_{s} \left[ \rho \right] = T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] + \int {\upsilon_{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} {\text{\rm d}}\vec{r} $$

The corresponding Euler–Lagrange equation is thus 1.19
$$\mu = \upsilon _{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \frac{{\delta T_{s} \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} $$

The quantity
$$ T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] $$ , although not the exact kinetic energy
$$ T\left[ \rho \right] $$ , is well-defined using orbitals
$$ \left\{ {\phi_{i} } \right\} $$ . It is a density functional, because the KS orbitals are implicit functionals of density.
$$ T_{s} $$ is the major contributor of
$$ T\left[ \rho \right] $$ . Its proper description is the key to the success of KS-DFT. Nevertheless, one has to notice that, by reintroducing the wavefunction, the full potential of DFT in having only three variables independent of system size could no longer be realized.

Now
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ in Eq. 1.10 can be reformulated as 1.20
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] = T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] + J\left[ \rho \right] + E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ and the corresponding Euler–Lagrange (Eq. 1.13) becomes 1.21
$$\mu = \upsilon _{{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \frac{{\delta T_{s} \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} + \frac{{\delta J\left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} + \frac{{\delta E_{{xc}} \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}}$$

Here
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ is the so-called exchange-correlation (xc) functional, which covers the residual part of the true kinetic energy (
$$ T_{c} = T - T_{s} $$ ) and the non-classic electrostatic interaction of electrons (
$$ E_{\text{ncl}} = V_{\text{ee}} - J $$ ). 1.22
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] = \left( {T\left[ \rho \right] - T_{s} \left[ \rho \right]} \right) + \left( {V_{\text{ee}} \left[ \rho \right] - J\left[ \rho \right]} \right) $$

The exact xc functional
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ is unknown, whose construction should be a relatively “easy” job as compared to the direct construction of
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ , as the former is a minor, while the latter is a major, contributor to the total energy functional
$$ E\left[ \rho \right] $$ .

Recall that the KS scheme starts by assuming the existence of
$$ \upsilon_{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ , which remains to be determined. By requiring the chemical potential of the non-interacting system (Eq. 1.19) to be equal to that of the real system (Eq. 1.21),
$$ \upsilon_{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ can then be obtained as 1.23
$$ \upsilon_{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \upsilon_{\text{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \upsilon_{J} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \upsilon_{\text{xc}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ where the external potential is given in Eq. 1.4, and the Coulomb as well as the xc potentials are given by 1.24
$$\upsilon _{J} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \frac{{\delta J\left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} = \int {\frac{{\rho \left( {\vec{r}'} \right)}}{{\left| {\vec{r}' - \vec{r}} \right|}}} {\rm{d}}\vec{r}^{\prime}$$
1.25
$$\upsilon _{{xc}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \frac{{\delta E_{{xc}} \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}}$$

Note that
$$ \upsilon_{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ depends on
$$ \rho $$ , via Eqs. (1.23)–(1.25), the KS Equation (1.15) must be solved iteratively. Furthermore, the exact xc functional is unknown, such that the exact xc potential, defined in Eq. 1.25, is unknown. Certain approximated
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ has to be used in practice. Thus, pursuing more and more accurate and reliable approximate xc functionals is the key issue in the development of density functional theory.

Section1.Heading: Approximations for the Commonly Used Exchange-Correlation Functionals

Section2.Heading: The Jacob’s Ladder
Section2.Para:
From the above section, we see that the Kohn–Sham scheme allows us to separate out
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ from
$$ F_{\text{HK}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ . This leaves finding an accurate form for
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ the last barrier to the finding of the ground state density and the ground state energy.

Various density functional approximations (DFAs) to the xc energy have been developed in recent decades [9–56]. They are proposed with different philosophies. Functionals may be categorized into non-empirical and empirical. The former are formulated only by satisfying some physical rules, (e.g. [9–16, 21–23, 31, 32]) while the later are made by fitting to the known results of atomic or molecular properties (e.g. [25, 26, 33, 38, 39, 45–48]). In practice, the most popular functionals seem to be those developed by a combination of these two approaches, i.e., a physically motivated form with a few parameters being optimized for better numerical performance (e.g. [19, 20, 28, 29, 34, 35, 43, 50, 54]).

Perdew proposed a useful scheme to categorize the existing functionals, which also points out the direction for future functional development. This scheme is known as the Jacob’s ladder (See Fig. 1.1), where functionals are grouped according to their complexity on rungs of the ladder, starting from the Hartree approximation on “earth” to the “heaven of chemical accuracy” [57, 58].
Fig. 1.1
Jacob’s ladder of approximate DFT methods

We will now briefly discuss the first four rungs of this ladder to introduce some of the most widely used xc functionals in the past and present. The focus of the present book is to introduce, from the next chapter, a new generation of functionals on the fifth rung.

Section2.Heading: The First Rung Functionals
Section2.Para:
Local density approximation (LDA [9–16]) is the foundation of most DFAs, representing the first rung of the Jacob’s ladder. In this approach, the real inhomogeneous system is divided into infinitesimal volumes. In each of the volumes, the electron density is taken to be constant. The xc energy for the density within each volume is then assumed to be the xc energy obtained from the uniform electron gas for that density. Thus, the total xc energy of the system can be written as 1.26
$$E_{{xc}}^{{LDA}} \left[ \rho \right] =\int\!\!\! {\rho \left ({\vec{r}} \right)\varepsilon _{{xc}}^{{LDA}} \left( {\left[ \rho \right];\vec{r}} \right){\rm{d}}\vec{r}} $$ where
$$ \varepsilon_{\text{xc}}^{\text{LDA}} $$ is the xc energy per particle.

It is usual to decompose
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ into its exchange
$$ E_{x} \left[ \rho \right] $$ and correlation
$$ E_{c} \left[ \rho \right] $$ components: 1.27
$$ E_{\text{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] = E_{x} \left[ \rho \right] + E_{c} \left[ \rho \right] $$

For LDA, the analytical expression for the exchange energy is known by Bloch and Dirac [11, 12]. 1.28
$$ E_{x}^{\text{LDA}} \left[ \rho \right] = - \frac{3}{4}\left( {\frac{3}{\pi }} \right)^{1/3} \int\!\! {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)^{4/3} } {\text{d}}\vec{r} $$ and 1.29
$$\varepsilon _{x}^{{LDA}} = - \frac{3}{4}\left( {\frac{3}{\pi }} \right)^{{1/3}} \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)^{{1/3}} $$

Slater proposed the
$$ X_{\alpha } $$ method which was once widely used in the solid state physics [13]. Although it actually differs from Eq. 1.28 for the prefactor, the name Slater is often used as a synonym for the LDA exchange energy,
$$ E_{x}^{S} $$ , involving the electron density raised to the
$$ {4 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {4 3}} \right. \kern-0pt} 3} $$ power.

In the literature, Eq. 1.29 is also often expressed in terms of the Wigner–Seitz radius
$$ r_{s} $$ [59], which corresponds to the radius of the effective volume containing one electron: 1.30
$$ r_{s} = \left( {\frac{3}{4\pi \rho }} \right)^{{{\raise0.7ex\hbox{$1$} \!\mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 3}}\right.\kern-0pt} \!\lower0.7ex\hbox{$3$}}}} $$

Thus 1.31
$$ \varepsilon_{x}^{S} = - \frac{3}{4}\left( {\frac{3}{2\pi }} \right)^{{{2 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {2 3}} \right. \kern-0pt} 3}}} \frac{1}{{r_{s} }} $$

The correlation energy is more complicated. It has been derived in the high and low density limits [60–63]. For the intermediate densities, the correlation energy has been determined to a high precision by quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) methods [64]. In order to use these results in DFT calculations, it is desirable to have a suitable analytic interpolation formula. Several such formulas have been constructed and all are considered as accurate fits [14–16]. The common LDA correlation functionals are Vosko, Wilk, and Nusair (VWN) [14], and Perdew-Zunger (PL) [15], and Perdew–Wang [16].

Below, we will discuss more on the VWN parameterization, which is given in Eq. 1.32 [14]. 1.32
$$\begin{array}{l} \varepsilon _{c}^{{P/F}} = A\left[ {\text{In}\frac{{y^{2} }}{{Y\left( y \right)}} + \frac{{2b}}{Q}tan^{{ - 1}} \frac{Q}{{2y + b}}} \right. \\ {\rm{ }}\left. { - \frac{{by_{0} }}{{Y\left( {y_{0} } \right)}}\left( {\text{In}\frac{{\left( {y - y_{0} } \right)^{2} }}{{Y\left( y \right)}} + \frac{{2(b + 2y_{0} )}}{Q}tan^{{ - 1}} \frac{Q}{{2y + b}}} \right)} \right] \\ \end{array} $$ where
$$y = r_{s}^{{{1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 2}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} 2}}} ,{\rm{ }}Y(y) = y^{2} + by + c,Q = (4c - b^{2} )^{{{1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 2}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} 2}}} $$ and P/F stands for the para/ferro magnetic case, respectively. For the paramagnetic case, the parameters fitted to QMC data are A = 0.0310907 (a.u.), y 0 = − 0.10498, b = 3.72744, c = 12.9352; while for the ferromagnetic case, the corresponding parameters are 2A = 0.0310907 (a.u.), y 0 = −0.32500, b = 7.06042, c = 18.0578. In the original VWN paper [14], parameters were also fitted to the Random Phase Approximation (RPA), where y 0 = −0.409286, b = 13.0720, c = 42.7198 for the paramagnetic case, and y 0 = −0.743294, b = 20.1231, c = 101.578 for the ferromagnetic case (with the same setting for A as in QMC). Note that different implementations have used different parameterizations which produce different numerical results and have caused some confusion. For example, Gaussian suite of program [65] uses the synonym VWN for the RPA parameterization and VWN5 for the QMC parameterization.

The extension of density functionals to spin-polarized systems is straightforward for exchange, where the exact spin-scaling is known as [66]: 1.33
$$ E_{x} \left[ {\rho_{\alpha } ,\,\rho_{\beta } } \right] = \frac{1}{2}\left( {E_{x} \left[ {2\rho_{\alpha } } \right] + E_{x} \left[ {2\rho_{\beta } } \right]} \right) $$ and 1.34
$$ \rho_{\alpha } + \rho_{\beta } = \rho $$

But for correlation further approximations must be employed. The spin-dependence of the correlation energy density,
$$ \varepsilon_{c} \left( {r_{s} ,\zeta } \right) $$ , is approached by introducing the relative spin-polarization [14]: 1.35
$$ \zeta = \frac{{\rho_{\alpha } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) - \rho_{\beta } \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}}{{\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} $$ where
$$ \zeta = 0 $$ corresponds to the paramagnetic spin-unpolarized situation
$$ \varepsilon_{c}^{P} \left( {r_{s} } \right) = \varepsilon_{c} \left( {r_{s} ,\,\zeta = 0} \right) $$ with
$$ \rho_{\alpha } = \rho_{\beta } $$ , whereas
$$ \zeta = \pm 1 $$ corresponds to the ferromagnetic situation
$$ \varepsilon_{c}^{F} \left( {r_{s} } \right) = \varepsilon_{c} \left( {r_{s} ,\,\zeta = \pm 1} \right) $$ where one spin density vanishes. The
$$ \zeta $$ -dependent correlation energy density
$$ \varepsilon_{c} \left( {r_{s} ,\,\zeta } \right) $$ is then constructed to interpolate these extreme values. Again, different interpolation formulas may be employed. For example, the Gaussian implementation [65] of VWN uses the formula suggested by von Barth and Hedin [10], while its VWN5 implementation uses a slightly more complicated form where a quality called spin stiffness,
$$ \alpha_{c} \left( {r_{s} } \right) $$ , was also fitted against Eq. 1.32 [14].
Thus we now have some commonly used acronyms for the LDA exchange-correlation functionals, namely SVWN, SVWN5, SPL as in Gaussian.

Section2.Heading: The Second Rung Functionals
Section2.Para: LDA is best suited in describing extended systems, such as metals, where the approximation of the uniform electron gas is most valid. To account for the rapidly varying electron densities of many other systems like atoms and molecules, improvements over LDA have to make the xc energies dependent not only on the electron density but also on derivatives of the density.

The second rung functionals are based on the so-called generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [17–20], where the first derivative of the density is also included as a variable. 1.36
$$E_{{xc}}^{{GGA}} \left[ \rho \right] = \int {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\varepsilon _{{xc}}^{{GGA}} \left( {\left[ {\rho ,\left| {\nabla \rho } \right|} \right];\vec{r}} \right){\rm{d}}\vec{r}} $$

Similarly, a GGA xc functional is also assumed to be separable, and the GGA exchange functional takes the general form as 1.37
$$ \varepsilon_{x}^{\text{GGA}} \left( {\rho ,\left. {\left| {\nabla \rho } \right|} \right)} \right. = \varepsilon_{x}^{\text{LDA}} \cdot F\left( s \right) $$ where F(s) is an enhancement factor and s (or similarly
$$ x = \left( {24\pi^{2} } \right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \cdot s $$ ) is the dimensionless reduced gradient defined as 1.38
$$ s = \frac{{\left| {\nabla \rho } \right|}}{{\left( {24\pi^{2} } \right)^{\frac{1}{3}} \rho^{\frac{4}{3}} }} $$

There are now many exchange functionals of the GGA type (e.g. [17–29]). They differ from each other in the form of the enhancement factor F(s). One of the most popular GGA exchange functionals was proposed by Becke, denoted as B or B88, whose F(s) takes the form as [19] 1.39
$$ F^{\text{B88}} \left( s \right) = \frac{{1 + s \cdot a_{1} \cdot \sinh^{ - 1} \left( {s \cdot a_{2} } \right) + a_{3} \cdot s^{2} }}{{1 + s \cdot a_{1} \cdot \sinh^{ - 1} \left( {s \cdot a_{2} } \right)}} $$

Another popular exchange functional is called PW91 (Perdew–Wang 1991) [21]. 1.40
$$ F^{\text{PW91}} \left( s \right) = \frac{{1 + s \cdot a_{1} \cdot \sinh^{ - 1} \left( {s \cdot a_{2} } \right) + \left( {a_{3} + a_{4} \cdot e^{{ - 100s^{2} }} } \right)s^{2} }}{{1 + s \cdot a_{1} \cdot \sinh^{ - 1} \left( {s \cdot a_{2} } \right) + a_{5} \cdot s^{d} }} $$

Here
$$ A_{x} = - \frac{3}{4}\left( {\frac{3}{\pi }} \right)^{1/3} $$ ,
$$ a_{2} = \left( {48\pi^{2} } \right)^{\frac{1}{3}} $$ , a 1 = 6·a 2,
$$ a_{3} = - \frac{{a_{2}^{2} }}{{2^{1/3} A_{x} }} \cdot \beta $$ ,
$$ a_{4} = \frac{10}{81} - a_{3} $$ ,
$$ a_{5} = \frac{{ - a_{2}^{4} \times 10^{ - 6} }}{{2^{1/3} A_{x} }} $$ , and d = 4. B88 contains one fitting parameter β. Becke obtained β = 0.0042 from fitting to Hartree–Fock (HF) exchange energies for the noble gas atoms [19]. PW91 adopted the B88 form by adding a 4 and a 5 to satisfy some physical constraints. PW91 is considered as non-empirical as it is an analytic fit to a numerical GGA obtained by real-space cutoff of the spurious long-range parts of the second-order gradient expansion of the exchange-correlation hole [21, 22].

PBE (Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof) [23] can be considered as a refinement of PW91. In PBE, the enhancement factor of the exchange functional is given by 1.41
$$ F^{\text{PBE}} \left( s \right) = 1 + \kappa - \frac{\kappa }{{\left( {1 + \frac{\mu }{\kappa }s^{2} } \right)}} $$ where κ = 0.804 is set to the maximum value allowed by the local Lieb-Oxford bound [23, 67] on E xc and μ = 0.21951 is set to recover the linear response of the uniform gas such that the effective gradient coefficient for exchange cancels that for correlation.

Note that the GGA functional form is usually too restrict to fulfill some important conditions simultaneously. For example, it is known that as r approaches infinity,
$$ \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right) $$ approaches
$$ \exp \left( { - \alpha \vec{r}} \right) $$ so that [19, 68] 1.42
$$\mathop {\lim }\limits_{{r \to \infty }} \varepsilon _{x} = - \frac{{\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}}{{2r}}$$

Levy and Perdew showed that some scaling properties can be satisfied if the asymptotic form of the functional for large s is
$$ s^{ - a} $$ , where
$$ a \ge {1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 2}} \right. \kern-0pt} 2} $$ (Condition 2) [69] 1.43
$$ \mathop {\lim }\limits_{s \to \infty } F\left( s \right) = \frac{1}{{s^{a} }}\left( {a \ge \frac{1}{2}} \right)\left( {{\text{Condition }}2} \right) $$ while the global version of the Lieb-Oxford bound requires that [23, 67] 1.44
$$ E_{x} \ge E_{\rm xc} \ge - 1.679\int {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)^{\frac{4}{3}} {\rm d} {\vec{r}}} \left( {{\text{Condition}}\, 3} \right) $$

Figure 1.2 depicts the F(s) functions. B88 fulfills Condition 1 by construction [19], but violates Conditions 2 and 3. PW91 does not obey Condition 1, but fulfills the other two conditions by adding a 4 and a 5 [22]. PBE meets only Condition 3. It was chosen to sacrifice Condition 2 to avoid the F(s) turnover of PW91, as it was suspected that this turnover would cause spurious wiggles in the exchange potential for large s [23]. While all three functionals recover the LDA limit as s → 0, the large s behavior cannot be uniquely determined (see Fig. 1.2). As the density is typically low and varies rapidly in the nonbonded region, proper large s behavior is important for the description of the nonbonded interactions [43].
Fig. 1.2
Enhancement factors for a set of GGA exchange functionals

There are similarly various GGA functionals being proposed for the correlation energy (e.g. [20, 22, 23]). The GGA correlation functional is usually expressed as: 1.45
$$E_{c}^{{GGA}} \left[ {\rho _{\alpha } ,\rho _{\beta } } \right] = \int {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\left[ {\varepsilon _{c}^{{LDA}} \left( {r_{s} ,\zeta } \right) + H\left( {r_{s} ,\zeta ,t} \right)} \right]} {\rm{d}}\vec{r}$$ where
$$ t = \frac{{\left| {\nabla \rho } \right|}}{{2gk_{s} \rho }} $$ is another scaled density gradient,
$$ g = \frac{1}{2}\left[ {\left( {1 + \zeta } \right)^{\frac{2}{3}} + \left( {1 - \zeta } \right)^{\frac{2}{3}} } \right] $$ is a spin-scaling factor and
$$ k_{s} = \left( {\frac{{4k_{F} }}{\pi }} \right)^{\frac{1}{2}} $$ is the Thomas–Fermi screening wave vector with
$$ k_{F} = \left( {3\pi^{2} \rho } \right)^{\frac{1}{3}} $$ being the local Fermi wave vector.

In the Perdew–Wang-91 correlation functional (
$$ E_{c}^{\text{PW91}} $$ ), H is expanded as [22] 1.46
$$ H^{\text{PW91}} = H_{0} + H_{1} $$
1.47
$$ H_{0} = g^{3} \frac{{\beta^{2} }}{2\alpha }\ln \left[ {1 + \frac{2\alpha }{\beta }\frac{{t^{2} + At^{4} }}{{1 + At^{2} + A^{2} t^{4} }}} \right] $$
1.48
$$H_{1} = \left( {\frac{{16}}{\pi }} \right)\left( {3\pi ^{2} } \right)^{{\frac{1}{3}}} \left[ {C_{c} \left( {r_{s} } \right) - C_{c} \left( 0 \right) - \frac{{3C_{x} }}{7}} \right]g^{3} t^{2} \exp \left[ { - 100g^{4} t^{2} \left( {\frac{{k_{s}^{2} }}{{k_{F}^{2} }}} \right)} \right]$$ with parameters
$$ A = \frac{2\alpha }{\beta }\frac{1}{{\exp \left[ {\frac{{ - 2\alpha \varepsilon_{c}^{LDA} \left( {r_{s} ,\zeta } \right)}}{{g^{3} \beta^{2} }}} \right] - 1}} $$ , α = 0.09, β = 0.066725, the Rasolt and Geldart constants (C
c [70]) and the Sham coefficient (C
x [71]).
$$ \varepsilon_{c}^{\text{LDA}} $$ is the Perdew–Wang’s parameterization
$$ \varepsilon_{c}^{\text{PW}} $$ [16].

In the well-established PBE correlation functional, only the first term in the PW91 correlation functional is kept [21–23]. This was derived to ensure that the PBE correlation functional reduces to the correct second-order gradient expansion in the slowly varying limit, and under uniform scaling of the density
$$ \left[ {\rho_{\gamma } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \gamma^{3} \rho \left( {\gamma \vec{r}} \right)} \right] $$ the PBE correlation energy correctly scales to a constant in the limit
$$ \gamma \to \infty $$ . In addition PBE uses α = 0.0716 instead of the α = 0.09 used in PW91. Note that the PBE form has been revised [27, 28] and the parameters have been optimized [28, 29].

LYP does not use the electron gas as the reference system, but considers instead short-range effects in the two-particle density matrix. It is a simplification of the Colle-Salvetti correlation functional which explicitly depends on the single-particle orbitals [72]. LYP contains four semiempirical parameters {a, b, c, d}, all from the underlying Colle-Salvetti functional and obtained from a fit to the He atom. Note that LYP is self-interaction free for any one-electron system, but its correlation energy erroneously vanishes for any ferromagnetic situation.

The LYP correlation functional is often combined with the B88 exchange functional, while the PBE correlation functional is meant to be combined with its own exchange functional to ensure a good behavior of the whole xc functional. Thus we now have three commonly used acronyms for the GGA exchange-correlation functionals, namely BLYP, BPW91, and PBE.

Section2.Heading: The Third Rung Functionals
Section2.Para:
The third rung functionals are the so-called meta-GGAs [30–33], which logically extend the GGA functionals by allowing the xc functionals to depend further on Laplacian
$$
abla ^{2} ho \left( {\vec{r}} ight)$$ , the second order derivative of the electron density. 1.50
$$E_{{xc}}^{{meta - GGA}} \left[ ho ight] = \int {ho \left( {\vec{r}} ight)\varepsilon _{{xc}}^{{meta - GGA}} \left( {\left[ {ho ,\left| {
abla ho } ight|,
abla ^{2} ho ,	au } ight];\vec{r}} ight){m{d}}\vec{r}} $$

More frequently, meta-GGAs include
$$ \tau $$ as the additional ingredient, which is the orbital kinetic energy density defined by 1.51
$$\tau _{\sigma } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{i}^{{occ}} {\left| {\nabla \phi _{{i\sigma }} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \right|^{2} } $$

Here
$$ \sigma $$ stands for either
$$ \alpha $$ or
$$ \beta $$ spin and
$$ \tau = \sum_{\sigma } {\tau_{\sigma } } $$ , while occ refers to occupied orbitals. The orbital kinetic energy density and the Laplacian of the density essentially carry the same information, since they are related via the orbitals and the effective potential of the KS equation [73, 74]. 1.52
$$\tau _{\sigma } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \sum\limits_{i}^{{occ}} {\varepsilon _{{i\sigma }} \left| {\phi _{{i\sigma }} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \right|^{2} } - \upsilon _{s}^{\sigma } \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\rho _{\sigma } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \frac{1}{4}\nabla ^{2} \rho _{\sigma } \left( {\vec{r}} \right)$$

This may also be seen from the gradient expansion for slowly varying densities [31]. 1.53
$$ \tau = \tau^{\text{TF}} + \frac{1}{9}\tau^{W} + \frac{1}{6}\nabla^{2} \rho + O\left( {\nabla^{4} \rho } \right) $$ with
$$ \tau^{\text{TF}} = \frac{3}{10}\left( {3\pi^{2} } \right)^{{{2 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {2 3}} \right. \kern-0pt} 3}}} \rho^{{{5 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {5 3}} \right. \kern-0pt} 3}}} $$ [2, 3, 13] the Thomas–Fermi kinetic energy density from uniform electron gas and
$$ \tau^{W} = \frac{{\left| {\nabla \rho } \right|^{2} }}{8\rho } $$ [31, 73–75] the von Weizsäcker kinetic energy density. As the representative meta-GGAs, we will introduce VSXC (van Voorhis-Scuseria) and TPSS (Tao-Perdew-Staroverov-Scuseria). While the former contains 21 parameters which are fitted to experimental data [30], the latter is a non-empirical version that improves over the PBE functional [32].

In VSXC, the exchange functional is expressed as [30] 1.54
$$E_{x}^{{VSXC}} \left[ {\rho _{\alpha } ,\rho _{\beta } } \right] = \sum\limits_{\sigma } {\int\!\! {\rho _{\sigma }^{{{3 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {3 4}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} 4}}} f\left( {x_{\sigma } ,z_{\sigma } } \right){\rm{d}}\vec{r}} } $$

Here
$$ x_{\sigma } $$ and
$$ z_{\sigma } $$ are defined as
$$ x_{\sigma } = \frac{{\left| {\nabla \rho_{\sigma } } \right|}}{{\rho_{\sigma }^{{{4 \!\mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {4 3}}\right.\kern-0pt} \!3}}} }} $$
and
$$ z_{\sigma } = 2\left( {\frac{{\tau_{\sigma } }}{{\rho_{\sigma }^ {{{5 \!\mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {5 3}}\right.\kern-0pt} \!3}}} }} - C_{F} } \right) $$ , respectively. This form was based on a density-matrix expansion, which was then modified through the introduction of 7 fit parameters {a, b, c, d, e, f, α} [30]. 1.55
$$ f\left( {x_{\sigma } ,\,z_{\sigma } } \right) = \frac{a}{{\gamma \left( {x_{\sigma } ,\,z_{\sigma } } \right)}} + \frac{{bx_{\sigma }^{2} + cz_{\sigma } }}{{\gamma^{2} \left( {x_{\sigma } ,\,z_{\sigma } } \right)}} + \frac{{dx_{\sigma }^{4} + {\text{e}}x_{\sigma }^{2} z_{\sigma } + fz_{\sigma }^{2} }}{{\gamma^{3} \left( {x_{\sigma } ,\,z_{\sigma } } \right)}} $$ with
$$ \gamma \left( {x_{\sigma } ,\,z_{\sigma } } \right) \equiv 1 + \alpha \left( {x_{\sigma }^{2} + z_{\sigma } } \right) $$ .

The correlation functional was constructed as 1.56
$$ E_{c}^{\text{VSXC}} = E_{c}^{\alpha \beta } + E_{c}^{\alpha \alpha } + E_{c}^{\beta \beta } $$
1.57
$$ E_{c}^{\sigma \sigma '} = \int\!\! {\varepsilon_{c}^{{{\text{LDA}},\,\sigma \sigma '}} f\left( {x,z} \right){\text{d}}\vec{r}} $$
1.58
$$ E_{c}^{\sigma \sigma } = \int\!\! {\varepsilon_{c}^{{{\text{LDA}},\,\sigma \sigma }} D_{\sigma } f\left( {x_{\sigma } ,\,z_{\sigma } } \right){\text{d}}\vec{r}} $$ where
$$ x^{2} \equiv x_{\alpha }^{2} + x_{\beta }^{2} $$ and
$$ z \equiv z_{\alpha } + z_{\beta } $$ .
$$ \varepsilon_{c}^{\text{LDA}} $$ is the Perdew–Wang’s parameterization
$$ \varepsilon_{c}^{\text{PW}} $$ with the spin components as defined by Stoll et al. [76]. The enhancement factor
$$ f\left( {x_{\sigma } ,\,z_{\sigma } } \right) $$ takes the same form as in the exchange functional. The fit parameters are listed in Table 1.1 [30].

Note that
$$ D_{\sigma } $$ is a dimensionless factor given by 1.59
$$ D_{\sigma } = 1 - \frac{{x_{\sigma }^{2} }}{{4\left( {z_{\sigma } + 2C_{F} } \right)}} $$
It is designed to be zero for any system with only one orbital, which guarantees that the correlation energy is zero for any one-electron system to be self-interaction error free.

In TPSS, the exchange functional is defined as [32] 1.60
$$E_{x}^{{TPSS}} \left[ \rho \right] = \int\!\!\! {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\varepsilon _{x}^{{LDA}} \left( {\left[ \rho \right];\vec{r}} \right)F^{{TPSS}} \left( {p,\tilde{z}} \right){\rm{d}}\vec{r}} $$

The enhancement factor
$$ F_{x}^{\text{TPSS}} \left( {p,\,z} \right) $$ is given by 1.61
$$ F^{\text{TPSS}} \left( {p,\,\tilde{z}} \right) = 1 + \kappa - \frac{\kappa }{{\left( {1 + \frac{{\tilde{x}}}{\kappa }} \right)}} $$ where
$$ \mu s^{2} $$ in
$$ F^{\text{PBE}} $$ (Eq. 1.41) is replaced by a function
$$ \tilde{x} $$ . 1.62
$$ \begin{gathered} \tilde{x} = \left\{ {\left[ {\frac{10}{81} + c\frac{{\tilde{z}^{2} }}{{\left( {1 + \tilde{z}^{2} } \right)^{2} }}} \right]p + \frac{146}{2025}\tilde{q}_{b}^{2} - \frac{73}{405}\tilde{q}_{b} \sqrt {\frac{1}{2}\left( {\frac{3}{5}\tilde{z}} \right)^{2} + \frac{1}{2}p^{2} } } \right. \hfill \\ \, \left. { + \frac{1}{\kappa }\left( \frac{10}{81} \right)^{2} p^{2} + 2\sqrt e \frac{10}{81}\left( {\frac{3}{5}\tilde{z}} \right)^{2} + e\mu p^{3} } \right\}\left( {1 + \sqrt e p} \right)^{ - 2} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$ with
$$ \tilde{z} = {{\tau^{W} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\tau^{W} } \tau }} \right. \kern-0pt} \tau } $$ ,
$$ \alpha = \frac{{\tau - \tau^{W} }}{{\tau^{\text{TF}} }} $$ ,
$$ p = s^{2} $$ the square of the reduced gradient, and
$$\tilde{q}_{b} = \frac{9}{{20}}\frac{{\left( {\alpha - 1} \right)}}{{\left[ {1 + b \cdot \alpha \left( {\alpha - 1} \right)} \right]^{{{1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 2}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} 2}}} }} + \frac{{2p}}{3}$$ . Here
$$ \mu = 0.21951 $$ ,
$$ \kappa = 0.804 $$ ,
$$ c = 1.59096 $$ and
$$ e = 1.537 $$ were fixed from some physical arguments [32], while b was chosen to be 0.40 [71]. Note that we have used symbols
$$ \tilde{x} $$ and
$$ \tilde{z} $$ here, rather than symbols
$$ x $$ and
$$ z $$ used in the original paper [32], as the latter have already been used in defining the VSXC functional [30].

In TPSS, the correlation functional is given by [32] 1.63
$$E_{c}^{{TPSS}} \left[ \rho \right] = \int\!\!\! {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\varepsilon _{c}^{{revPKZB}} \left[ {1 + d{\rm{ }}\tilde{z}^{3} \varepsilon _{c}^{{revPKZB}} } \right]{\rm{d}}\vec{r}} $$ with 1.64
$$ \varepsilon_{c}^{\text{revPKZB}} = \varepsilon_{c}^{\text{PBE}} \left[ {1 + C\left( {\zeta ,\xi } \right)\tilde{z}^{2} } \right] - \left[ {1 + C\left( {\zeta ,\xi } \right)} \right]\tilde{z}^{2} \sum\limits_{\sigma } {\frac{{\rho_{\sigma } }}{\rho }} \tilde{\varepsilon }_{c} $$
1.65
$$C\left( {\zeta ,\xi } \right) = \frac{{C\left( {0,0} \right) + 0.87\zeta ^{2} + 0.50\zeta ^{4} + 2.26\zeta ^{6} }}{{\left\{ {1 + \frac{{\xi ^{2} }}{2}\left[ {\frac{1}{{\left( {1 + \zeta } \right)^{{{4 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {4 3}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} 3}}} }} + \frac{1}{{\left( {1 - \zeta } \right)^{{{4 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {4 3}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} 3}}} }}} \right]} \right\}^{4} }}$$
1.66
$$ \tilde{\varepsilon }_{c}^{\sigma } = \hbox{max} \left\{ {\varepsilon_{c}^{\text{PBE}} \left( {\rho_{\sigma } ,\,0,\,\nabla \rho_{\sigma } ,\,0} \right),\,\varepsilon_{c}^{\text{PBE}} \left( {\rho_{\alpha } ,\,\rho_{\beta } ,\,\nabla \rho_{\alpha } ,\,\nabla \rho_{\beta } } \right)} \right\} $$ where
$$ \zeta $$ is the relative spin polarization (Eq. 1.35),
$$ \xi = \frac{{\left| {\nabla \zeta } \right|}}{{2\left( {3\pi^{2} \rho } \right)^{{{1 \!\mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 3}}\right.\kern-0pt} \!3}}} }} $$ .
$$ C\left( {0,0} \right) $$ and d were chosen to be 0.53 and 2.8 au−1, respectively [77]. Note that some parameters in TPSS has been optimized or revised [78].

Section2.Heading: The Fourth Rung Functionals
Section2.Para:
As in Eqs. 1.26, 1.36, and 1.50, the xc functional is defined as an integral over
$$ \vec{r} $$ of a function of
$$ \vec{r} $$ which we call an energy density. An LDA corresponds to a ‘local functional of the density’ where the energy density at
$$ \vec{r} $$ is determined only by the electron density at
$$ \vec{r} $$ . An GGA is a ‘semilocal functional of the density’ in the sense that the energy density at
$$ \vec{r} $$ is determined by the electron density in an infinitesimal neighborhood of
$$ \vec{r} $$ . As energy density at
$$ \vec{r} $$ which employs kinetic energy density
$$ \tau $$ is computed from the density and the orbitals in an infinitesimal neighborhood of
$$ \vec{r} $$ , an meta-GGAs is also ‘semilocal functionals of the density and the orbitals.’ Such (semi)locality gives rise to much of the computational convenience of DFT. However, these functionals are best suited for the description of slow varying density. For a better description of a finite system, there is a demand for certain nonlocal component.

With the KS orbitals at hand, the exchange energy can be explicitly written as 1.67
$$ E_{x}^{\text{HF}} = - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{ij}^{occ} {\iint {\frac{{\phi_{j}^{*} \left( {\vec{r}'} \right)\phi_{i}^{*} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\phi_{j} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)\phi_{i} \left( {\vec{r}'} \right)}}{{\left| {\vec{r}' - \vec{r}} \right|}}}} {\text{d}}\vec{r}'{\text{d}}\vec{r} $$

The superscript HF recognizes the fact that it shares the same form as in the Hartree–Fock (HF) theory, which however uses the HF orbitals.
$$ E_{x}^{\text{HF}} $$ is nonlocal which depends on two spatial variables (r, r′).

It would be reasonable to expect that good results were obtainable if the approximate (semi)local exchange functionals were replaced with this exact equation for exchange energy: 1.68
$$ E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{DFA}} = E_{x}^{\text{HF}} + E_{c}^{\text{DFA}} $$

Regretfully, this form only gave acceptable results for one-center systems (atoms and ions) [4, 34, 35, 79], and was not very successful in describing chemical bonds in molecules [4, 34, 35, 80]. It is difficult to develop a (semi)local
$$ E_{c}^{\text{DFA}} $$ that can match well with the nonlocal
$$ E_{x}^{\text{HF}} $$ .

It should be emphasized that
$$ J\left[ \rho \right] $$ as in Eq. 1.9 includes electron self-interaction explicitly. An approximated
$$ E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{DFA}} $$ is unable to remove this self-interaction error completely, which has been related to many deficiencies of common DFAs [81–85]. This is the major advantage to use
$$ E_{x}^{\text{HF}} $$ , which is one-electron self-interaction error free. On the other hand, as opposed to
$$ E_{x}^{\text{HF}} $$ , the local or semilocal exchange functional
$$ E_{x}^{\text{DFA}} $$ was shown to incorporate an mimic of ‘static correlation’
$$ \left( {E_{x}^{\text{DFA}} = E_{x}^{\text{HF}} + E_{c}^{\text{Sta}} } \right) $$ , while the corresponding approximation for correlation energy models ‘dynamic correlation’
$$ \left( {E_{c}^{\text{DFA}} \approx E_{c}^{\text{Dyn}} } \right) $$ [26, 86]. 1.69
$$ E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{DFA}} = E_{x}^{\text{DFA}} + E_{c}^{\text{DFA}} \approx E_{x}^{\text{HF}} + E_{c}^{\text{Sta}} + E_{c}^{\text{Dyn}} $$

Hence, a correct choice that compromises the needs between elimination of self-interaction and inclusion of nondynamic correlation is to hybrid the right-hand sides of Eqs. 1.68 and 1.69. The simplest choice is a linear combination, giving rise to a new class of xc functionals denoted as the hybrid xc functionals [34, 35, 37]. 1.70
$$ E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{hyb}} = a_{0} E_{x}^{\text{HF}} + \left( {1 - a_{0} } \right)E_{x}^{\text{DFA}} + E_{c}^{\text{DFA}} $$

This was first introduced by Becke in 1993 [34], who used a different theoretical rationale, namely the adiabatic connection path (see Sects. 2.2
and 2.4
) [34, 35, 37, 50, 87–89]. Ideally, it would be desirable to optimize
$$ a_{0} $$ for each system and property, but Perdew, based on the accuracy of the fourth order perturbation theory for most molecules, suggests
$$ a_{0} $$ = 0.25 as the best single choice. This has led to the PBE0 hybrid functional where
$$ E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{DFA}} $$ is the PBE GGA functional [37, 40, 41].

One of the most popular functionals is based on Becke’s three-parameter scheme (B3) [35]. 1.71
$$ E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{B3 hyb}} = a_{0} E_{x}^{\text{HF}} + \left( {1 - a_{0} } \right)E_{x}^{\text{LDA}} + a_{x} \Updelta E_{x}^{\text{GGA}} + E_{c}^{\text{LDA}} + a_{c} \Updelta E_{c}^{\text{GGA}} $$

The parameters
$$ \left\{ {a_{0} = 0.20, \, \,a_{x} = 0.78,\, \, a_{c} = 0.81} \right\} $$ were obtained by fitting to 56 atomization energies, 42 ionization energies, 8 proton affinities, and 10 first row atomic energies. During his fit, Becke has originally chosen
$$ E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{GGA}} = E_{\text{xc}}^{\text{BPW91}} $$ [35]. This hybrid functional is then called B3PW91. Later it appeared [36] that a combination of the B3 scheme with the BLYP xc functional [19, 20] gave better results. This has brought about the most widely used functional in chemistry B3LYP. Although LYP was not separable as PW91 (i.e., Eq. 1.45 vs 1.49) by construction, it was assumed
$$ \Updelta E_{c}^{\text{LYP}} = E_{c}^{\text{LYP}} - E_{c}^{\text{LDA}} $$ [90], where
$$ E_{c}^{\text{LDA}} $$ can be the VWN5 parameterization in some implementations, or the VWN RPA parameterization in some other implementations such as in Gaussian [65]. This is often a source of confusion.

The success, as well as the failure, of B3LYP has initiated the development of many new hybrid functionals (e.g. [38–56]). A recent important development in DFT is the M06 family of functionals (M06, M06-2X and M06-HF, and M06-L) [33, 48], which currently provides the highest accuracy with a broad applicability for chemistry. The exchange for the M06 family consists of a linear combination of two terms: one term comes from the PBE exchange functional [23] multiplied by a kinetic-energy–density enhancement factor [33], and the other term is the VSXC exchange functional [30]. The correlation for the M06 family also involves two terms: one term is similar to the correlation functional in BMK [45] modified by Becke’s self-interaction correction factor [91], the other term comes from the VSXC correlation functional [30]. M06, M06-2X, M06-HF are hybrid methods with increasing amount of HF exchange (0.27, 0.54, 1.00, respectively) while M06-L is a pure DFT, with around 40 parameters fitted against different data sets to emphasize different applications. Thus M06 is of general purpose, M06-2X is recommended for chemistry of the main group elements, M06-HF is for charge-transfer states in electronic spectroscopy, and M06-L for transition metal chemistry [33, 48].

[97]. fErrors (Ref.–Calc.) for binding energy and equilibrium distance in kcal/mol and Å, respectively. The reference data, 5.44 kcal/mol and 2.948 Å, are taken from Ref. [44, 98, 99]. g From Ref. [100].h From Ref. [101]

As shown by the data in Table 1.2, the LDA (SVWN) method gives good molecular structures and vibrational frequencies in the strongly bound systems as in the G2-1 set. The mean absolute deviations (MADs) associated with SVWN are 0.017 Å and 75 cm−1, respectively, which is a significant improvement over HF (0.022 Å and 144 cm−1) and is comparable to those of MP2 (0.014 Å and 99 cm−1), while the latter is much more time-consuming and computational resource demanding. LDA does not work for hydrogen bonded (HB) systems as well as for van der Waals interactions. Besides, its errors for bond dissociation energies (BDEs) of covalent molecules (43.5 kcal/mol for the G2-1 set) are too big to be useful.

GGAs, as exemplified by data of BPW91 and BLYP in Table 1.2, improve over LDA dramatically on BDE calculations. MADs for the G2-1 set are of order 6-10 kcal/mol. They give increasingly satisfied molecular structures, especially for the HB systems, with MADs around 0.003 Å. However, GGAs apparently fail for van der Waals interactions.

The general trends for the improvement along LDA → GGA → Hybrid GGA are clearly seen in the description of covalently bound molecules of main group elements. For the G2-1 set, B3LYP only possesses an MAD of 0.004 Å for geometry predictions, being comparable to those obtained by the CCSD(T) method using basis set at the triple-zeta quality. B3LYP’s error for BDEs is halved as compared to those of GGAs. However, along with GGAs, hybrid GGAs do not work for van der Waals interactions. All these functionals leave much room for further improvement.
